questions.questionText: A construction crane lifts a $!$500 \text{ kg}$!$ steel beam vertically $!$20 \text{ m}$!$. The lifting force increases linearly from $!$5000 \text{ N}$!$ at the start to $!$10000 \text{ N}$!$ at $!$5 \text{ m}$!$, remains constant at $!$10000 \text{ N}$!$ from $!$5 \text{ m}$!$ to $!$15 \text{ m}$!$, and then decreases linearly back to $!$5000 \text{ N}$!$ at $!$20 \text{ m}$!$. Determine the total work done by the crane on the beam during this lift in Joules.

steps.stepText: Let's start by identifying the fundamental expression used to calculate the work done by a force. Which of the following formulas correctly represents work done by a force?

Great. Now, let’s analyze the first segment of the lift from $!$0 \text{ m}$!$ to $!$5 \text{ m}$!$, where the force increases linearly from $!$5000 \text{ N}$!$ to $!$10000 \text{ N}$!$. Calculate the work done in this segment by finding the average force and multiplying it by the displacement. What is the work done in this segment?

Now, move to the second segment from $!$5 \text{ m}$!$ to $!$15 \text{ m}$!$, where the force remains constant at $!$10000 \text{ N}$!$. Multiply the constant force by the distance (remembering that the distance covered is the difference between 15 m and 5 m). What is the work for this segment?

Next, consider the final segment of the lift from $!$15 \text{ m}$!$ to $!$20 \text{ m}$!$, where the force decreases linearly from $!$10000 \text{ N}$!$ back to $!$5000 \text{ N}$!$. Similar to the first segment, compute the work done by using the average force method. What is the work for this segment?
Finally, add the work values from all three segments to obtain the total work done by the crane on the beam. What is the total work done?

questions.questionText: An electric delivery van, initially at rest, accelerates to a speed of 20 m/s on a level road. During this acceleration, the electric motor performs 500,000 J of work. Calculate the kinetic energy gained by the van.

steps.stepText: Let's start by identifying the theorem that connects the net work done on an object to its change in kinetic energy. Please select the formula that expresses this concept.

Great, now that we've recalled the work-kinetic energy theorem, consider that the van initially was at rest (meaning its initial kinetic energy was zero). Knowing the work performed is 500,000 J, calculate the change in kinetic energy.
Now, using your previous result, determine the final kinetic energy gained by the van. What is the numerical value of the kinetic energy after the work has been done?
